action.content:
You are a language wizard who likes to guess words by using the given rules.

Welcome to Wordle! You have six attempts to guess the target word, a valid English word of five lowercase letters (a-z). Please use the tags "explanation:" and "guess:" to provide a concise explanation for each guess.

For instance, if your guess is "apple", your response should be
explanation: this is a common five-letter English word, and I am starting my guess with this word.
guess: apple

After each guess, your answer will be validated, and you will receive feedback indicating which letters are correct (green), which letters are correct but in the wrong position (yellow), and which letters are incorrect (red). This feedback can be useful in determining which letters to include or exclude in your next guess.

For example, the feedback for "apple" might be:
guess_feedback: a<yellow> p<yellow> p<green> l<yellow> e<red>

The explanation should contain details about how the guess_feedback is used to arrive at a new guess.

Do not generate any other text.

Let's begin with your first guess.

explanation: I'm starting with a common five-letter English word that has a good balance of vowels and consonants, increasing the chances of getting at least one letter correct.
guess: house

attempts = 1
target_word = kappa
guess = house
guess_feedback = h<red> o<red> u<red> s<red> e<red>

guess_feedback: h<red> o<red> u<red> s<red> e<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: Since all letters in the previous guess were incorrect, my next guess will be a completely new set of letters, choosing a word that is also very common and has a different combination of vowels and consonants to maximize the chance of hitting at least one correct letter.
guess: bread

attempts = 2
target_word = kappa
guess = bread
guess_feedback = b<red> r<red> e<red> a<yellow> d<red>

guess_feedback: b<red> r<red> e<red> a<yellow> d<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: With the letter "a" being marked as yellow, it means "a" is in the word but not in the correct position, so my next guess will include "a" in a different position, and I will introduce new letters that are commonly used in many English words to try and find more correct letters.
guess: stamp

attempts = 3
target_word = kappa
guess = stamp
guess_feedback = s<red> t<red> a<yellow> m<red> p<yellow>

guess_feedback: s<red> t<red> a<yellow> m<red> p<yellow>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: The letters "a" and "p" are marked as yellow, indicating they are in the word but not in the correct positions, so my next guess will try to utilize these letters in different positions, and introduce new letters that are frequently paired with "a" and "p" in English words to increase the chances of finding more correct letters.
guess: paste

attempts = 4
target_word = kappa
guess = paste
guess_feedback = p<yellow> a<green> s<red> t<red> e<red>

guess_feedback: p<yellow> a<green> s<red> t<red> e<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: With "a" now marked as green, it means "a" is in the correct position, and "p" is still yellow, indicating it's in the word but not in the right spot, so my next guess will keep "a" in the same position and try different positions for "p", while introducing new letters that often appear with "a" and "p" in English words.
guess: patch

attempts = 5
target_word = kappa
guess = patch
guess_feedback = p<yellow> a<green> t<red> c<red> h<red>

guess_feedback: p<yellow> a<green> t<red> c<red> h<red>

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: Since "a" is in the correct position and "p" is in the word but not in the right spot, my next guess will maintain "a" in the same position, try "p" in a different position, and introduce new letters that are commonly found with "a" and "p" to increase the chances of guessing the word correctly.
guess: papel
Guesser Error: NOT_VALID_WORD_FOR_GAME while parsing Player 1's (model: Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct) response

Your guess is not a valid word for this game. Please try again.

Provide your response only in this format.
explanation: details
guess: word

explanation: Considering "a" is in the correct position and "p" is in the word, my next guess will be a valid English word that keeps "a" in the same position and tries "p" in a different position, while also introducing new letters that are commonly paired with "a" and "p".
guess: panic

attempts = 6
target_word = kappa
guess = panic
guess_feedback = p<yellow> a<green> n<red> i<red> c<red>
game_result = LOSS

guess_explanation: I'm starting with a common five-letter English word that has a good balance of vowels and consonants, increasing the chances of getting at least one letter correct.

Since all letters in the previous guess were incorrect, my next guess will be a completely new set of letters, choosing a word that is also very common and has a different combination of vowels and consonants to maximize the chance of hitting at least one correct letter.

With the letter "a" being marked as yellow, it means "a" is in the word but not in the correct position, so my next guess will include "a" in a different position, and I will introduce new letters that are commonly used in many English words to try and find more correct letters.

The letters "a" and "p" are marked as yellow, indicating they are in the word but not in the correct positions, so my next guess will try to utilize these letters in different positions, and introduce new letters that are frequently paired with "a" and "p" in English words to increase the chances of finding more correct letters.

With "a" now marked as green, it means "a" is in the correct position, and "p" is still yellow, indicating it's in the word but not in the right spot, so my next guess will keep "a" in the same position and try different positions for "p", while introducing new letters that often appear with "a" and "p" in English words.

Considering "a" is in the correct position and "p" is in the word, my next guess will be a valid English word that keeps "a" in the same position and tries "p" in a different position, while also introducing new letters that are commonly paired with "a" and "p".
